channel.title: KenSmith tweets
channel.description: A feed of recent tweets from KenSmith.

item.description: Lots of action at the bird feeder this morning, even one redwing blackbird, a bird I associate with country roads running between Midwestern farm fields, not with our small-city neighborhoods.
I was skimming a 1960 article in a Soviet anthropology journal and noticed how positively the word “propaganda” is used in its pages. I assume there’s a paper trail that explains that…

Some mornings you open your eyes to eye-opening sentences and images on FB. “Pollution makes great sunsets.” “…like a true addict, I wanted all of my recovery to come at once.” “We stopped in Belize and visited a toucan sanctuary. It was my favorite part of the trip.” https://t.co/5f87QZEsGb
@elizmccracken I’ve added the ending of Dreamsong 282 to my repertoire, but mostly to say to myself. https://t.co/uhfWeukI37
@HormoneHangover @PYeerk I thought the Science Friday radio show was talking in very fuzzy, nearly un-pin-down-able ways about that term in last week's show.
"Americans, by and large, are putting the pandemic behind them." (Privilege makes that possible.) See also: Racism, putting behind them; Poverty, putting behind them; Etc. https://t.co/3Niceb2AyO

Should Poem A and Poem B be added to the book manuscript? Each one is only six lines long. You can read them in this thread below. Merci.
Poem A https://t.co/FnRoaNdkGQ
Poem B https://t.co/Cz5yOaqXeR

A tweet got mucho readers, then @Twitter’s algo had Twitter’s brain ask me to sign up for the professional Twitter thing. I tried to see what in the world that actually means but the explanation web page neglected to explain. Bye, T-brain. Billing you for ten minutes of my life.
@toebean_peets Just living life as a go-between…
RSS feed updates sports scores on @WatchfireSigns digital billboards. https://t.co/wWv9r844DF https://t.co/LGP4IrUHDG
Getting started here in our section of South Bend, Indiana. https://t.co/i4pMojM5tz

Responsibility to renewable systems would be a satisfying and enduring cultural story much better than our current one, which glorifies the frantic and ecstatic strip-mining of the planet’s resources, crashing the natural systems that make the resources in the first place.

First day of spring semester, 1977, walking on a campus sidewalk. Ahead on the cement, I see a piece of paper money. Picked it up, looked around, said, “It’s a $100 bill.” The young woman walking behind me said, “I should have gotten out of bed five minutes earlier today.”
Local news model in Santa Cruz, built on 17 tech tools, publishing in a variety of digital formats, with ambitious goals. https://t.co/erZRitryDq
If memory serves me, part of what brought the Cuban missile crisis to an end was the U.S. agreeing to remove some missiles from near the Soviet Union, in Turkey.
Trying to capture rock music in sentences. Good luck. https://t.co/03pPFnSPc6

1/3 The Stones are on the box, loud enough so I notice the drums. Next song, again it's the drums. I usually think the Stones are about the sting of the guitars and the backbone and sneer and syrup of the voice and the words, but no, tonight the drummer is the front man.
2/3 Music teaches young people how to feel something, I think my sister said. Maybe that's the wound steel of the strings stretched and plucked, doing their part, but tonight the drums seem to say: don't just feel something, you'd better move.
3/3 The backbone, the attitude, well, we need that whenever we move out into the streets. The words might help us know why that is. Help us set sweet against bitter as we go.
And then one of the cruel songs comes on.

Inside Wire: Colorado Prison Radio "beams music, stories, information, and entertainment into prisons across Colorado ... and beyond. Our programs are created by incarcerated media producers for incarcerated listeners." https://t.co/njgMUzSqKJ

@cameronponsonby @blzzrd I grew up in a family of goalkeepers and goalie coaches in St. Louis, Missouri, one of the U.S.’s few real old football towns. Everyone I show this article to texts me saying, “Yes!” My brother’s son said, “Dad, you used to shout those same things at the TV when I was a kid.”

When a person or a country decides to make war, no only do they destroy visible and tangible things, but they also steal hours of everyday life for years to come. Putin is a thief, one among many. https://t.co/eG0cIJECr5
Overheard: "The bar has been set so low you have to dig to find it."
